segment.source: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.
segment.target: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: ID3DDevice::CreateBuffer
segment.target: ID3DDevice::CreateBuffer

segment.source: ID3DDeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers
segment.target: ID3DDeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer

segment.source: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.
segment.target: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.

segment.source: At this point, let's examine the hardcoded model for the cube mesh we are using.
segment.target: At this point, let's examine the hardcoded model for the cube mesh we are using.

segment.source: Both representations have the vertices organized as a triangle list (as opposed to a strip or other more efficient triangle layout).
segment.target: Both representations have the vertices organized as a triangle list (as opposed to a strip or other more efficient triangle layout).

segment.source: All vertices in both representations also have associated indices and color values.
segment.target: All vertices in both representations also have associated indices and color values.

segment.source: Much of the Direct3D code in this topic refers to variables and objects defined in the Direct3D project.
segment.target: Much of the Direct3D code in this topic refers to variables and objects defined in the Direct3D project.

segment.source: Here's the cube for processing by OpenGL ES 2.0.
segment.target: Here's the cube for processing by OpenGL ES 2.0.

segment.source: In the sample implementation, each vertex is 7 float values: 3 position coordinates followed by 4 RGBA color values.
segment.target: In the sample implementation, each vertex is 7 float values: 3 position coordinates followed by 4 RGBA color values.

segment.source: And here's the same cube for processing by Direct3D 11.
segment.target: And here's the same cube for processing by Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Reviewing this code, you notice that the cube in the OpenGL ES 2.0 code is represented in a right-hand coordinate system, whereas the cube in the Direct3D-specific code is represented in a left-hand coordinate system.
segment.target: Reviewing this code, you notice that the cube in the OpenGL ES 2.0 code is represented in a right-hand coordinate system, whereas the cube in the Direct3D-specific code is represented in a left-hand coordinate system.

segment.source: When importing your own mesh data, you must reverse the z-axis coordinates for your model and change the indices for each mesh accordingly to traverse the triangles according to the change in the coordinate system.
segment.target: When importing your own mesh data, you must reverse the z-axis coordinates for your model and change the indices for each mesh accordingly to traverse the triangles according to the change in the coordinate system.

segment.source: Assuming that we have successfully moved the cube mesh from the right-handed OpenGL ES 2.0 coordinate system to the left-handed Direct3D one, let's see how to load the cube data for processing in both models.
segment.target: Assuming that we have successfully moved the cube mesh from the right-handed OpenGL ES 2.0 coordinate system to the left-handed Direct3D one, let's see how to load the cube data for processing in both models.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: Step 1: Create an input layout
segment.target: Step 1: Create an input layout

segment.source: In OpenGL ES 2.0, your vertex data is supplied as attributes that will be supplied to and read by the shader objects.
segment.target: In OpenGL ES 2.0, your vertex data is supplied as attributes that will be supplied to and read by the shader objects.

segment.source: You typically provide a string that contains the attribute name used in the shader's GLSL to the shader program object, and get a memory location back that you can supply to the shader.
segment.target: You typically provide a string that contains the attribute name used in the shader's GLSL to the shader program object, and get a memory location back that you can supply to the shader.

segment.source: In this example, a vertex buffer object contains a list of custom Vertex structures, defined and formatted as follows:
segment.target: In this example, a vertex buffer object contains a list of custom Vertex structures, defined and formatted as follows:

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0: Configure the attributes that contain the per-vertex information.
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0: Configure the attributes that contain the per-vertex information.

segment.source: In OpenGL ES 2.0, input layouts are implicit; you take a general purpose GL\_ELEMENT\_ARRAY\_BUFFER and supply the stride and offset such that the vertex shader can interpret the data after uploading it.
segment.target: In OpenGL ES 2.0, input layouts are implicit; you take a general purpose GL\_ELEMENT\_ARRAY\_BUFFER and supply the stride and offset such that the vertex shader can interpret the data after uploading it.

segment.source: You inform the shader before rendering which attributes map to which portions of each block of vertex data with glVertexAttribPointer.
segment.target: You inform the shader before rendering which attributes map to which portions of each block of vertex data with glVertexAttribPointer.

segment.source: In Direct3D, you must provide an input layout to describe the structure of the vertex data in the vertex buffer when you create the buffer, instead of before you draw the geometry.
segment.target: In Direct3D, you must provide an input layout to describe the structure of the vertex data in the vertex buffer when you create the buffer, instead of before you draw the geometry.

segment.source: To do this, you use an input layout which corresponds to layout of the data for our individual vertices in memory.
segment.target: To do this, you use an input layout which corresponds to layout of the data for our individual vertices in memory.

segment.source: It is very important to specify this accurately!
segment.target: It is very important to specify this accurately!

segment.source: Here, you create an input description as an array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures.
segment.target: Here, you create an input description as an array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures.

segment.source: Direct3D: Define an input layout description.
segment.target: Direct3D: Define an input layout description.

segment.source: This input description defines a vertex as a pair of 2 3-coordinate vectors: one 3D vector to store the position of the vertex in model coordinates, and another 3D vector to store the RGB color value associated with the vertex.
segment.target: This input description defines a vertex as a pair of 2 3-coordinate vectors: one 3D vector to store the position of the vertex in model coordinates, and another 3D vector to store the RGB color value associated with the vertex.

segment.source: In this case, you use 3x32 bit floating point format, elements of which we represent in code as .
segment.target: In this case, you use 3x32 bit floating point format, elements of which we represent in code as .

segment.source: You should use types from the DirectXMath library whenever you are handling data that will be used by a shader, as it ensure the proper packing and alignment of that data.
segment.target: You should use types from the DirectXMath library whenever you are handling data that will be used by a shader, as it ensure the proper packing and alignment of that data.

segment.source: (For example, use XMFLOAT3 or XMFLOAT4 for vector data, and XMFLOAT4X4 for matrices.)
segment.target: (For example, use XMFLOAT3 or XMFLOAT4 for vector data, and XMFLOAT4X4 for matrices.)

segment.source: For a list of all the possible format types, refer to DXGI\_FORMAT.
segment.target: For a list of all the possible format types, refer to DXGI\_FORMAT.

segment.source: With the per-vertex input layout defined, you create the layout object.
segment.target: With the per-vertex input layout defined, you create the layout object.

segment.source: In the following code, you write it to m\_inputLayout, a variable of type ComPtr (which points to an object of type ID3D11InputLayout).
segment.target: In the following code, you write it to m\_inputLayout, a variable of type ComPtr (which points to an object of type ID3D11InputLayout).

segment.source: fileData contains the compiled vertex shader object from the previous step, Port the shaders.
segment.target: fileData contains the compiled vertex shader object from the previous step, Port the shaders.

segment.source: Direct3D: Create the input layout used by the vertex buffer.
segment.target: Direct3D: Create the input layout used by the vertex buffer.

segment.source: We've defined the input layout.
segment.target: We've defined the input layout.

segment.source: Now, let's create a buffer that uses this layout and load it with the cube mesh data.
segment.target: Now, let's create a buffer that uses this layout and load it with the cube mesh data.

segment.source: Step 2: Create and load the vertex buffer(s)
segment.target: Step 2: Create and load the vertex buffer(s)

segment.source: In OpenGL ES 2.0, you create a pair of buffers, one for the position data and one for the color data.
segment.target: In OpenGL ES 2.0, you create a pair of buffers, one for the position data and one for the color data.

segment.source: (You could also create a struct that contains both and a single buffer.) You bind each buffer and write position and color data into them.
segment.target: (You could also create a struct that contains both and a single buffer.) You bind each buffer and write position and color data into them.

segment.source: Later, during your render function, bind the buffers again and provide the shader with the format of the data in the buffer so it can correctly interpret it.
segment.target: Later, during your render function, bind the buffers again and provide the shader with the format of the data in the buffer so it can correctly interpret it.

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0: Bind the vertex buffers
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0: Bind the vertex buffers

segment.source: In Direct3D, shader-accessible buffers are represented as D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structures.
segment.target: In Direct3D, shader-accessible buffers are represented as D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structures.

segment.source: To bind the location of this buffer to shader object, you need to create a CD3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC structure for each buffer with ID3DDevice::CreateBuffer, and then set the buffer of the Direct3D device context by calling a set method specific to the buffer type, such as ID3DDeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers.
segment.target: To bind the location of this buffer to shader object, you need to create a CD3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC structure for each buffer with ID3DDevice::CreateBuffer, and then set the buffer of the Direct3D device context by calling a set method specific to the buffer type, such as ID3DDeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers.

segment.source: When you set the buffer, you must set the stride (the size of the data element for an individual vertex) as well the offset (where the vertex data array actually starts) from the beginning of the buffer.
segment.target: When you set the buffer, you must set the stride (the size of the data element for an individual vertex) as well the offset (where the vertex data array actually starts) from the beginning of the buffer.

segment.source: Notice that we assign the pointer to the vertexIndices array to the pSysMem field of the D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structure.
segment.target: Notice that we assign the pointer to the vertexIndices array to the pSysMem field of the D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structure.

segment.source: If this isn't correct, your mesh will be corrupt or empty!
segment.target: If this isn't correct, your mesh will be corrupt or empty!

segment.source: Direct3D: Create and set the vertex buffer
segment.target: Direct3D: Create and set the vertex buffer

segment.source: Step 3: Create and load the index buffer
segment.target: Step 3: Create and load the index buffer

segment.source: Index buffers are an efficient way to allow the vertex shader to look up individual vertices.
segment.target: Index buffers are an efficient way to allow the vertex shader to look up individual vertices.

segment.source: Although they are not required, we use them in this sample renderer.
segment.target: Although they are not required, we use them in this sample renderer.

segment.source: As with vertex buffers in OpenGL ES 2.0, an index buffer is created and bound as a general purpose buffer and the vertex indices you created earlier are copied into it.
segment.target: As with vertex buffers in OpenGL ES 2.0, an index buffer is created and bound as a general purpose buffer and the vertex indices you created earlier are copied into it.

segment.source: When you're ready to draw, you bind both the vertex and the index buffer again, and call glDrawElements.
segment.target: When you're ready to draw, you bind both the vertex and the index buffer again, and call glDrawElements.

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0: Send the index order to the draw call.
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0: Send the index order to the draw call.

segment.source: With Direct3D, it's a bit very similar process, albeit a bit more didactic.
segment.target: With Direct3D, it's a bit very similar process, albeit a bit more didactic.

segment.source: Supply the index buffer as a Direct3D subresource to the ID3D11DeviceContext you created when you configured Direct3D.
segment.target: Supply the index buffer as a Direct3D subresource to the ID3D11DeviceContext you created when you configured Direct3D.

segment.source: You do this by calling ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer with the configured subresource for the index array, as follows.
segment.target: You do this by calling ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer with the configured subresource for the index array, as follows.

segment.source: (Again, notice that you assign the pointer to the cubeIndices array to the pSysMem field of the D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structure.)
segment.target: (Again, notice that you assign the pointer to the cubeIndices array to the pSysMem field of the D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA structure.)

segment.source: Direct3D: Create the index buffer.
segment.target: Direct3D: Create the index buffer.

segment.source: Later, you will draw the triangles with a call to ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed (or ID3D11DeviceContext::Draw for unindexed vertices), as follows.
segment.target: Later, you will draw the triangles with a call to ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed (or ID3D11DeviceContext::Draw for unindexed vertices), as follows.

segment.source: (For more details, jump ahead to Draw to the screen.)
segment.target: (For more details, jump ahead to Draw to the screen.)

segment.source: Direct3D: Draw the indexed vertices.
segment.target: Direct3D: Draw the indexed vertices.

segment.target: Port the shader objects

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: When structuring your Direct3D, separate the code that calls methods on ID3D11Device into a method that is called whenever the device resources need to be recreated.
segment.target: When structuring your Direct3D, separate the code that calls methods on ID3D11Device into a method that is called whenever the device resources need to be recreated.

segment.source: (In the Direct3D project template, this code is in the renderer object's CreateDeviceResource methods.
segment.target: (In the Direct3D project template, this code is in the renderer object's CreateDeviceResource methods.

segment.source: The code that updates the device context (ID3D11DeviceContext), on the other hand, is placed in the Render method, since this is where you actually construct the shader stages and bind the data.
segment.target: The code that updates the device context (ID3D11DeviceContext), on the other hand, is placed in the Render method, since this is where you actually construct the shader stages and bind the data.
